title: 106_s2776
content: The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" increases the limitation on charitable deduction for contributions for medical research. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" increases the limitation on charitable deduction for contributions for medical research to 80 percent of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" increases the limitation on charitable deduction for contributions for medical research to 80 percent of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year, with a carryover provision for excess contributions. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" allows excess contributions for medical research to be carried over and treated as a medical research contribution in the following 10 years. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" allows excess contributions for medical research to be carried over and treated as a medical research contribution in the following 10 years, as defined in subparagraph (C)(iv). The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" allows excess contributions for medical research to be carried over and treated as a medical research contribution in the following 10 years, as defined in regulations. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code specify that these contributions are separate from other types of contributions. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow excess contributions for medical research to be treated separately and carried over for up to 10 years. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions made in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000, and to contributions made on or before December 31, 2000, to the extent that a deduction would be allowed under section 170 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. Treatment of certain incentive stock options. AMT Adjustments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding incentive stock options, with an exception for medical research stock transfers. Medical research stock transfer refers to the transfer of stock traded on an established securities market or acquired through the exercise of an incentive stock option. Medical research stock transfer involves the exercise of an incentive stock option within the same taxable year as the transfer occurs. Nonrecognition of certain incentive stock options is addressed in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new paragraph regarding medical research stock transfers. This amendment applies to stock transfers made after the enactment of the Act.
